The Commander in Chief, United States Fleet has by
reference (a) directed that the following shall apply relative to
the handling of this copy of this report:
(a) IT IS RECLASSIFIED AS SECRET AND SHALL BE SAFEGUARDED
IN ACCORDANCE WITH THE PROVISION OF ARTICLE 76, U.S.
NAVY REGULATIONS, 1920.
(b) INFORMATION PERTINENT AND NECESSARY TO THE FUNCTIONS
OF THE ACTIVITY TO WHICH ADDRESSED MAY BE EXTRACTED,
GIVEN A PROPRIATE SECURITY CLASSIFICATION, AND MADE
AVAILABLE TO THOSE WITHIN THAT ACTIVITY WHO NEED TO
KNOW IT.
(c) REPORTS SHALL BE DESTROYED BY BURNING AS SOON AS NO
LONGER REQUIRED. REPORT OF DESTRUCTION IS NOT REQUIRED.
(d) TRANSMISSION BY REGISTERED MAIL WITHIN THE CONTINENTAL
LIMITS OF THE UNITED STATES IS AUTHORIZED.
SECRET
With are
S. STOVALL, Jr
10/8/45

3:
U.S.S. COBIA - Sixth War Patrol - report of.
A - PROLOGUE
The COBIA arrived in Fremantle on 18 June 1945 after her
fifth war patrol. The refit was conducted by the U.S.S. CLYTIE
and Submarine Division 301.
Major changes accomplished were the installation of:
ST Radar, 5" gun forward in lieu of 4" gun, dummy log, D.R.T. in
control room, twin 20mm forward, and directional A.P.R.
The refit was completed on 3 July at which time Commander
A.L. BECKER, was relieved of command by Lieutenant Commander
F.N. RUSSELL. There were no other changes in officer personnel.
Training period was conducted under Captain Jesse L. HULL
during which three exercise and four special torpedoes were
fired.
The original departure date was set back two days by one
day in dock to renew both propellers (sound test showed them
noisy) and repack stern tubes and one day to replace unsatis-
factory attack scope.

Dived. Plane sighted at range of about 4 miles.
They definitely have us.
Surfaced. Three engines.
In view of the following considerations decided to
open out from coast to about 40-50 milos.
(1) Wo have been detected.
(2) There is no traffic along coast.
(3) If wo are not forced to dive too often, we can
make Sunda Strait the morning of the 26th and
thus save a day.
(4) We are needlessly alerting the area which the
TRUMP and TIPTOE will patrol.
APR Contact at 108 mc's. Land based and sweeping.
Looks like it is located in vicinity of Tjilatjap.

Picked up Tokitsu Sho bearing 350°T range 26,000

Contact bearing 059°T range 8,200 yards. Target
tracked at 9 knots on course 300°T. Went to
battle stations, made ready tubos, and commenced
closing in an attempt to identify contact. At
4,000 yards target was barely visible. About this
time target presented 170° anglo on the bow. Decided
it was a small patrol boat patrolling strait.
Turned away and headed for diving point at end of
swept channel. Secured from battle stations. Lost
target at 10,000 yards. Avoided contact at 2,700
yards, bearing 190°T. Not soon or hoard. Lost at
seen
4,000 yards.

19:
U.S.S. COBIA - Sixth War Patrol
C - WEATHER
-
report of. (continued).
Weather conditions were in accordance with those shown
on pilot charts and sailing directions.
D - TIDAL INFORMATION
Currents encountered were closely related to the direction
of the monsoon. Sunda Strait, July 26th, a current of 1.5
knots setting 325°T. Karimata Strait, July 28th, a current of
0.5 knots setting 340°T.
Currents off Formosa were as indicated in Sailing Directions.
However, within ten miles of the coast counter currents of 0.5
to 0.9 knots setting parallel to the coastline were encountered.
E - NAVIGATIONAL AIDES.
-
Hydro
Off Takao a red can buoy in position 22-48.5N, 119-58E
was observed. This appears to mark the end of an authorized
navigational channel into and out of the minefields.
F - SHIP CONTACTS.
None.
- 17 -
Iyptia
19
20:
U.S.S. COBIA - Sixth War Patrol - report of. (continued).
G - AIRCRAFT CONTACTS.
Aircraft posed no great problem nor inconvenience.
On July 24th off southern coast of Java the three contacts
wore picked up low by lookouts and the SD was in use at the
time. They are believed to be the diroot result of being
detected by radar early in the morning and most probably
came from bases near Surubaya.
ATTACK DATA.
None.
I - MINES.
Minefields off southwestern Formosa restricted our
movements to the extent that they prevented a close watch
being maintained off Takao, the only logical place for traffic
to be moving. No floating minos soen.
J - ANTI SUBMARINE MEASURES AND EVASION TACTICS.
J
Buships
ORT
Nonc.
NRL
K - MAJOR DEFECTS.
Enginooring:
On number two main engine the cylinder head
on number ton unit dovolopod a 3/4" crack near a holding
down bolt which permitted water leakage into the cylinder.
Causo was undotermined and tho trouble was romodied by re-
placing with a spiro. Lator in the run a four inch crack ap-
poared in the ongino frame at the forward inboard corner.
Fextra
- 18 -
20
21:
U.S.S. COBIA - Sixth War Patrol - report of. (continued).
L - RADIO.
Reception of Radio Subic was excellent except on July
20th from 0130 - 0600 in approximate position 26-47.45
111-49.42 where it was not possible to pick up the signal.
From 0600 until mid-afternoon the signal was too weak to
copy and schodulo was taken from VIXO's rebroadcast on 9250.
On July 24th, whon forced down by planes, ten numbers
were missed and were not repeated that night. Jamming was
negligiblo and ineffective and equipment functioned well
throughout tho run. It is felt that the extremely short
range of VHF is a handicap - more than 8,000 yards was too
distant to work and caused some delay on the morning of
August 1st in organizing search for some downod fliors.
Communications on life guard woro good.
M - RADAR.
ORI
NRL
Little conclusive information about radar equipment
this run. Tho SJ was used only on land masses and was satis-
factory in its operation. On a 10,000 foot peak we had second
return echoes at 120,000 yards. American subs were picked up
at 10,000 yards but small native craft were missed at 3,000.
No data is availablo on ST bocause it was not used. The SD
offered no great advantage because lookouts had the planes low
and far bofore they came into radar range. On one occasion
the IFF was used on what looked like an A-20 but no response
was received.
APR was a big aid and wo appreciated our newly installed
directional antennae. The list of contacts is as follows:-

The information furnishod on radar stations on Formosa
was very good. Wo were not bothered as a result of radar
contacts and managed to koop from being picked up by surface
search sets by using land massos as shields whenever in close.

(3)
(3) The Commander in Chief, U.S. Pecific Fleet.
The Commander Submarine Force, Pacific Fleet,
Administration.
U.S.S. COBIA(SS245) - Report of Sixth War Patrol.
1.
The sixth war potrol of the U.S.S. COBI was the
first for Lieutenant Commander F.N. Russell as commanding officer.
2.
This patrol was broken up by a one days stay at
Subic Bay, after which the COBIA patrolled southwest of Formosa
performing lifeguard duties.
3.
The patrol was of thirty-five days duration of which
eight days were spent in the area. No opportunity to rescue
aviation personnel afforded itself, and no contacts worthy of
torpedoes were made.
4.
The Administrative Division Commander congratulates
the commanding officer, officers and crew of the U.S.S. COBIA on
the return from their last war patrol.
1 Vom Hou
Wm.H. BROCKMAN, Jr.

The Commander Submarine Force, Pacific Fleet..
The Commander in Chief, United States Fleet.
The Commander in Chief, U.S. Pacific Fleet.
U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) - Report of Sixth War Patrol
(18 July to 22 August 1945).
11r
10 0609
1.
The sixth war patrol of the COBIA, under the command of Lieutenant
Commander F. N. Russell, U.S. Navy, was devoted to lifeguard duties. Except for
two days of searching for aviators off the entrance to the Gulf of Siam while on-
route to her area, this patrol was conducted off the southwest coast of Formosa.
No opportunities were afforded to rescue any air force personnel
2.
or to inflict damage upon the enemy.
3.
4.
Award of Submarine Combat Insignia for this patrol is not authorized
The Force Commandor congratulates the commanding officer, officers,.
and crew of the COBIA for the completion of this patrol and welcomes thom to the
Central Pacific.
DISTRIBUTION:
G. C. CRAWFORD,
(Complete Reports)
Chief of Staff.
